header.title: MAGIC SECRETS
header.category: Western Esotericism, Grimoire Tradition, Folk Magic

central_thesis: Guidon's 'Magic Secrets' presents a syncretic system of operative folk magic primarily focused on the protection, healing, and control of animals (sheep and horses), as well as counteracting malevolent spells and finding hidden treasures. It uniquely blends orthodox Christian invocations with cryptic Latin phrases and explicit appeals to both saints and a distinct hierarchy of named demonic/familiar entities.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introduction to Guidon's Practice
structure_content.summary: This section introduces Guidon as a practitioner of effective and infallible secrets for healing and counter-charms. He operates publicly and privately, motivated by charity, healing both rich and poor, and is admired for destroying evil spells. His methods have proven effective beyond doubt across Pays de Caux and Normandy.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Practice of Guidon, to destroy a Spell
structure_content.summary: Guidon's general practice for destroying spells involves ancient rituals including conjurations, exorcisms, gospels, and prayers. For humans, he uses Holy Water (baptismal), makes the sign of the Cross, aspersions with a blessed palm branch, and a cross on the forehead with his thumb. For bewitched animals, he substitutes Holy Water with salted water prepared with blood from the afflicted animal. He recites an orison from the 'Enchiridion of Pope Leo' (1660) and undertakes a nine-day novena of prayer and fasting.

structure_content.chapter_title: To destroy all spells (General)
structure_content.summary: This ritual requires placing salt in a glass, the quantity dependent on the number of bewitched animals. A specific incantation, 'Herego gomet hunc gueridans sesserant deliberant amei,' is recited over the salt. The practitioner then circles the animals three times, starting from the direction of the rising sun, throwing a pinch of salt on each animal while repeating 'Herego, etc.'

structure_content.chapter_title: The Great Exorcism to destroy all evil spells
structure_content.summary: A comprehensive exorcism to remove evil spells affecting humans or making animals unreasonable. It involves directly addressing the 'Demon' to leave the body of the afflicted, tracing the sign of the Holy Cross on the forehead and chest, and invoking the Father, Son, and Holy Ghost. The ritual includes a lengthy prayer to God and Jesus Christ to cast mercy upon the servant, break chains, and fill them with grace. It concludes by commanding the 'filthy Spirit' to leave in the name of the Holy Trinity and declares the presence of 'the Cross of Our Lord Jesus Christ' and 'the Lion of the Tribe of Judah, the root of David' against 'baleful enemies.'

structure_content.chapter_title: To destroy all spells and to compel the person who caused the evil
structure_content.summary: For an animal cursed to death, the heart is removed and placed on a clean plate. Nine hawthorn spikes (or new nails) are progressively stuck into the heart, each with a specific Latin or cryptic invocation (e.g., 'Adibaga, Sabaoth, Adonay,' 'Qui sussum mediator agros gaviol valax,' 'Mortus cum fice sunt et per flagellationem Domini nostri Jesu Christi'). A nail is then pierced through the heart while calling upon entities to undo the evil. The heart is placed in a bag and hung in a chimney. For nine consecutive days, the heart is removed, thorns re-inserted in different spots with the corresponding words. If the malefactor does not appear to beg for mercy, the heart is roasted over burning embers to cause their death.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Castle of Goodness for Horses / Protection of the Flock (Salt Magic)
structure_content.summary: This extensive protection ritual for horses (and sheep, later adapted) begins by placing salt on a plate, facing the rising sun, and kneeling with an uncovered head. The salt is conjured in the names of 'Disole, Soffée,' 'Gloria, Dorianté, and Galiane' to keep the animals healthy, strong, and subject to the practitioner's will. The ceremony is repeated at other cardinal quarters. Remaining salt is mixed with blood from an animal (e.g., horse), applied while invoking 'Grapin' and stating 'Horse, I bleed you with the hand that God has given me.' Horn from the animal's right hoof (or wool/horsehair) is formed into crosses, layered with salt, and sealed with wax/candle into a ball. This ball is used to rub the animals daily for a specific period (1, 2, 3, 7, 9, or 11 days), with timing dependent on moon phases for non-urgent cases. The afterword and footnotes discuss the parallels to malefic magic involving toads and how 'bad shepherds' use similar methods to curse flocks, which Guidon's method aims to counteract.

structure_content.chapter_title: A Charm for Protection of One's Will (Herd)
structure_content.summary: This spell invokes specific entities: 'STARIN, Astarot, Bahol, Satarin,' to guard the practitioner's herd, offering a white or black beast as payment. A cryptic word, 'hurlupapin,' is recited. Salt is then cast, similar to the 'Castle of Goodness' method, with the additional phrase: 'Gupin struck and the great fell; it is Cain who does that to you.' The animals are then rubbed while repeating these words. The footnotes acknowledge the demonic nature of some invoked names and the ambiguity of 'Cain.'

structure_content.chapter_title: Guard, or protection, against mange, scabs and rot
structure_content.summary: This ritual for sheep involves recalling 'Saviour of the World' (Jesus), 'Holy Virgin,' and 'St. John his shepherd.' The practitioner says five 'Our Fathers' and five 'Hail Marys,' invoking Lady St. Genevieve. The spell commands 'Mange' to be banished, dissolved, and confounded, in the name of 'Living God,' 'Virgin Mary,' and 'Holy Spirit.' It frames salt as a 'divine offering' crucial for all actions, protecting the flock from various ailments and predators. A Mass of the Holy Spirit is recommended.

structure_content.chapter_title: Protection against Scab / Another Protection for Sheep
structure_content.summary: For scab, salt is consecrated with 'Panem cœlestem accipiat sit nomen Domine invocabis,' then cast and rubbed onto animals while reciting 'Eum ter ergo docentes omnes gentes baptisantes eos. In nomine Patris, etc.' A further protection involves invoking God, Herve, St. John, Joseph, Nicodemus, and casting salt with 'Volo et vono Baptista Sancta Agala tum est.' Another variation invokes God and St. Requier (adversary of devils) to corrupt spells, applying consecrated salt ('Casta sacravera viva corpus Domini nostri Jesu Christi qui tima menta Deus; in nomine Patri, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti. Amen.').

structure_content.chapter_title: Secret for protecting Sheep from Wolves
structure_content.summary: The practitioner faces the rising sun and repeats a specific invocation five times (or once for five days). This prayer calls upon 'the Lamb of Humility' (Jesus) and 'Ave Maria' to protect the flock and commands the 'grey and grabbing beast' (wolf) to depart. The ritual includes explicitly invoking 'Father, Son, and Holy Spirit,' and 'St. Cerf,' concluding with 'Retreat, O Satana.' Salt is cast with the words 'Vanus vanes Christus vaincus, attack salt soli, attack St. Silvain in the name of Jesus.' The footnotes highlight the syncretism of invoking Christian figures alongside 'Satana' and 'St. Silvain' (likely a christianized Silvanus, a Roman god of woods and fields).

structure_content.chapter_title: The Poppet Spell
structure_content.summary: A dangerous and controversial spell to 'unite them, unite them, wed us and wed them, untie us and wed them to Beelzebub.' The explicit invocation of Beelzebub marks this as a distinctly demonic operation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Protection of Horses (Demonic Invocations)
structure_content.summary: This ritual conjures salt, described as 'formed in the foam of the sea,' to bring happiness and benefit to the master. It directly invokes a hierarchy of entities: 'Crouay,' 'Don,' 'Satan,' 'Leot,' 'Valiot,' 'Rou,' and 'Rouvayet,' commanding them as 'servants.' The salt is cast while saying 'Fisti Christi Belial.' The afterword discusses these names as potentially deriving from an unrecorded tradition, possibly related to romance language roots or solar deities, noting the power and potential 'painful' effects of invoking 'Rouvayet.'

structure_content.chapter_title: Protection from Rabbits
structure_content.summary: To protect crops, rabbit pellets and five pieces of tile (from a procession or cemetery) are collected. Facing the rising sun, kneeling, and bareheaded, the practitioner makes crosses over salt and invokes 'dant,' 'sant,' 'Heliot,' 'Valiot,' 'Rou,' and 'Rouvayet,' commanding them as servants to protect the crop. A dung pellet is placed in a hole in the ground with an invocation to 'Rou and Rouvayet.' Salt is then placed on the pellets, and a piece of broken tile/brick on top. The practitioner knocks the tile with their left heel, turning right, repeating the invocation. This process is repeated at the four corners and center of the field, concluding with sprinkling salt while invoking the 'anchor of the Virgin.'

structure_content.chapter_title: To calm an Animal
structure_content.summary: Two lengths of straw are used to form a cross (one knotted, the other laid over it). The practitioner then says: 'Anchor of God, Anchor of the Virgin, Anchor of the Devil: Satan, go forth to all the devils.' Throwing the cross over the animal's snout while kneeling with these words is said to allow one to carry the animal safely.

structure_content.chapter_title: To be Hard (Protection from Assault)
structure_content.summary: This spell involves reciting cryptic words ('VALANDA jacem rafit massif excorbis anter valganda zazar,' 'Bourbelet, Barlet, Amer come to surround me, as Judas betrayed our Lord'). These words are to be written on paper and carried around the neck, and spoken when in danger. Guidon himself was reputedly saved from a severe attack using this method.

structure_content.chapter_title: For discovering Treasure
structure_content.summary: In the suspected location of treasure, the ground is struck three times with the left heel. Turning to the left, the practitioner says: 'Sadies satani agir fons toribus; come to me, Seradon, who will be called Sarietur.' This is repeated three more times. Success is indicated by hearing something whispered in the ear.

structure_content.chapter_title: To stop a team of horses, or send a rider in the wrong direction
structure_content.summary: This infernal spell requires a nail forged during Midnight Mass. The nail is driven into the hoofprints of the horses. Alternatively, a scab or similar from the horse is used, with the invocation: 'Scab - I conjure you in the name of Lucifer, Beelzebuth and Satanas, the three princes of all the devils, that you must stop.' The words are repeated for nine successive days, during which all Christian acts must be eschewed. The afterword notes this spell identifies horses with demons and controls them via 'superior powers of Hell.'

structure_content.chapter_title: Counter-Charm (for horses)
structure_content.summary: A counter-charm against malevolent magic affecting horses: 'HOSTIA sacra vera corrum, in repelling the great demon of hell, all words, enchantments and-characters that have been said, read, and performed on the body of my living horses, they are now broken and shattered, stand back.' This invokes the 'Holy True Victim' (Christ) to undo demonic work.

structure_content.chapter_title: To make Lambs fair and strong
structure_content.summary: The firstborn or best lamb is chosen. The practitioner raises it from the ground, snout first, and says three times: 'Ecce lignum crucem in quo salu mundi crucem' (Behold the wood of the cross on which the salvation of the world hung). The lamb is lowered and raised again with the same words.

structure_content.chapter_title: Protection against all firearms
structure_content.summary: To protect against firearms, the practitioner says: 'STAR which guides the weapon today, I bewitch by a jig, I say you so, that you obey me: in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of Satanatis.' A cross is made. The footnotes suggest this is an ambivalent spell, replacing the Holy Ghost with a form of Satan.

structure_content.chapter_title: Against soreness of the muzzle and Fevers
structure_content.summary: For muzzle soreness and fevers in sheep, the practitioner turns towards the sunrise, opens the animal's jaws, and says three times: 'Brac +, Cabrac +, Carabra +, Cadebrac +, Cabracam +, I heal you.' These words are blown into the jaws each time. The same words, written on paper and worn around the neck for nine days, are also said to cure fevers. A sign of the cross is made when marked above.

structure_content.chapter_title: Against inflammation of the saliva glands in Horses
structure_content.summary: For inflamed saliva glands in a horse (specified by color and owner), the practitioner invokes God and the 'blessed St. Eloy' (patron saint of smiths) to heal 'these red swellings, or whatever colour they may be, or the thirty-six varieties of other sicknesses,' in the name of the 'Father, Son, and Holy Ghost.'

structure_content.chapter_title: To heal Sprains
structure_content.summary: This involves kneeling and saying five 'Our Fathers' and five 'Hail Marys.' The practitioner then says: 'TAY de satay suratay avalde, walk,' while striking the horse's shoe three times (left hoof if it's the near side). This method is also applicable to humans.

structure_content.chapter_title: To prevent a flock from touching seedlings
structure_content.summary: A piece of silver is hung from the neck of one of the sheep. Nine times, the practitioner says: 'Satan Satourne, speak of Gricacoeur incarnate lord of Nazareth; I request and command you, and humbly conjure you, that you come to keep and let pass my living flock of beasts this evening, this day, and this morning, saying hurlupupin.' The footnotes mention the demonic nature of this spell.

structure_content.chapter_title: To heal a beast suffering soreness of the Muzzle / Against the Heaves
structure_content.summary: For muzzle soreness, the afflicted beast has the following words said three times on its head: 'In tes daleme bouis, vins Divernas Sathan.' For the heaves, the horse's mouth is opened, and the same words are blown into it three times. The footnotes identify 'Sathan' as Satan, indicating a demonic appeal.

structure_content.chapter_title: Against a sore Muzzle / Against Mange
structure_content.summary: For a sore muzzle, holy water is applied with a fingertip to the bottom of the jaws, saying: '+ Christus Brutus et dutus est Vanum.' For mange, a cake is prepared from wheat, oil, salt, and blood from three animals, pounded together, wrapped in paper, and cooked in hot coals. This cake is then used to rub the animals, while repeating the phrase: '+ Christus Brutus et dutus est Vanum.' The footnotes explain this as a shocking, blasphemous spell, implying Christ is a 'fool and powerless.'

structure_content.chapter_title: Against Haemorrhoids
structure_content.summary: The practitioner uses the middle finger of their left hand to apply saliva from their mouth to the haemorrhoids, saying: 'Skewers, go away, God curses you; in the name of the Father, of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit.' This is followed by a nine-day regimen of saying Pater Nosters and Ave Marias, with the count decreasing daily (nine on day one, eight on day two, etc.).

structure_content.chapter_title: Against Epilepsy or Falling Sickness
structure_content.summary: The practitioner speaks into the right ear of the afflicted person: 'Oremus praeceptis salutaribus moniti.' The Lord's Prayer is then added. It is stated that before these prayers are finished, the illness will be relieved.

structure_content.chapter_title: Enchantment to stop Blood / Counter-Charm / Against Fire
structure_content.summary: To stop blood, the practitioner recites: 'SANGUIS mane in te sicut fecit Christus in sanguis mane in tua vena sicut Christus in sua poenat sanguis mane fixus sicut quando fuit crucifixus.' A general counter-charm invokes 'ECCE Crucem Domini, fugite partes adversae, vicit leo de tribu Juda, radix David.' For protection against fire, the invocation is: 'IN te, Domine, speravi, non confundar in aeternum.' These spells demonstrate a range of applications for immediate, specific needs.

structure_content.chapter_title: Against Fevers (Human)
structure_content.summary: This spell describes Jesus's life, fasting, and betrayal, then commands 'Fever third, Fever fourth, Fever of whatever sort you be' to leave the body in the name of Jesus. It invokes Holy Mary, St. Michael, Jesus, Maria, St. Joseph, and St. Catherine for protection. The words are written on paper, followed by the afflicted person's name, and worn around the neck. Daily, before eating, five Pater Nosters and five Ave Marias are said in front of an image of the Virgin.

key_concepts.definition: Guidon's practice demonstrates a blend of traditional Christian elements (prayers, saints, Holy Water, crosses) with pre-Christian or ambiguous (potentially demonic) invocations and practices (e.g., animal heart rituals, specific entities like Crouay, Sathan, Beelzebub), common in rural magical traditions of the period.

A central operative component, salt is consecrated (sometimes with blood) and used for protection, healing, purification, and as a medium to compel entities or destroy evil spells. Its application often involves specific directional movements and verbal formulas.

A powerful, coercive, and potentially lethal ritual aimed at revealing or punishing a malefactor. It involves the ritualistic insertion of thorns or nails into the heart of a bewitched animal over a nine-day period, culminating in roasting the heart if the malefactor does not yield, causing their death. This practice aims to create a magical link between the victim, the spell, and the original caster.

A recurring temporal framework for many rituals, mirroring Catholic novenas. This period is used for sustained magical operations, building power, or ensuring the full effect of a spell, often involving daily repetition of prayers or actions.

Guidon's system features a distinct hierarchy of named entities (e.g., Crouay, Don, Satan, Valiot, Leot, Rou, Rouvayet, Heliot, Reveillot, STARIN, Astarot, Satarin, Beelzebub, Lucifer) invoked for various purposes, including protection, compulsion, and treasure discovery. These entities often act as 'servants' to the practitioner, suggesting a pact or command structure. Some invocations are ambiguous, blending Christian and potentially blasphemous elements.

A key operative aspect where rituals are designed not just to alleviate the effects of a spell, but to actively force the person who cast the malevolent magic to reveal themselves or suffer consequences, including death, thereby providing redress or vengeance.

The practices are rooted in 17th-century Norman French rural traditions, reflecting the specific socio-cultural and religious environment where 'Cunning Men' operated. This context highlights the practical necessity for protecting livelihoods (animals) and dealing with perceived magical threats, often under the shadow of witchcraft accusations.

practical_system.description: Guidon's practical system is a detailed compilation of spells and counter-charms, often involving ritual acts, specific invocations, and the creation of charged objects. The core mechanics rely on the principle of magical linkage (e.g., between animal, spell, and caster), sympathetic magic (e.g., thorns in a heart), and the power of invoked names (both divine and demonic). Many rituals utilize the consecration and application of salt as a versatile magical agent. The efficacy is often tied to repetitive actions over specific periods (e.g., nine days), adherence to directional alignments (e.g., facing the rising sun), and the practitioner's focused intention and command. The system is notably pragmatic, addressing a wide array of specific agricultural and personal problems with concrete, step-by-step instructions.
tools: Salt (consecrated, sometimes mixed with animal blood)
Virgin paschal wax or blessed candle
Pieces of tile or brick (from procession/cemetery)
Paper and writing implements (for talismans, sometimes white ink on black paper)

General spell destruction with salt (circling animals, specific incantations like 'Herego gomet')
The Great Exorcism (direct address to demon, invocations of Trinity and saints)
Compelling a malefactor via animal heart ritual (hawthorn spikes/nails, specific incantations like 'Adibaga, Sabaoth, Adonay,' 'Mortus cum fice,' 'Avir sunt,' followed by roasting)
Protecting horses and sheep (salt consecration, invoking 'Disole, Soffée,' 'Gloria, Dorianté, Galiane,' 'Grapin,' and entities like 'STARIN, Astarot, Satarin, Crouay, Rou, Rouvayet')
Protection from wolves (invoking 'Lamb of Humility,' 'Ave Maria,' 'St. Cerf,' commanding 'Satana,' with salt and 'St. Silvain')
Protection from rabbits for crops (rabbit pellets, tile pieces, dung, salt, invoking 'Heliot, Valiot, Rou, Rouvayet')
Calming animals (straw cross, invoking 'Anchor of God, Virgin, Devil: Satan')
Gaining 'hardness' or protection from assault (cryptic words 'VALANDA jacem rafit,' 'Bourbelet, Barlet, Amer' written and carried)
Discovering treasure (striking ground, invoking 'Sadies satani agir fons toribus,' 'Seradon, Sarietur')
Stopping horses or misdirecting riders (Midnight Mass nail in hoofprints, or scab with invocation of 'Lucifer, Beelzebuth, Satanas')
Counter-charms for horses ('HOSTIA sacra vera corrum')
Making lambs fair and strong ('Ecce lignum crucem' invocation)
Protection against firearms ('STAR which guides the weapon,' invoking 'Father, Son, and of Satanatis')
Healing muzzle soreness and fevers in sheep ('Brac, Cabrac' series, blowing into jaws)
Healing inflammation of saliva glands in horses (invoking God and 'St. Eloy')
Healing sprains (prayers, striking horse shoe with 'TAY de satay suratay avalde')
Preventing flock from touching seedlings (silver piece, invoking 'Satan Satourne, Gricacoeur,' 'hurlupupin')
Healing muzzle soreness and heaves in horses (invoking 'Divernas Sathan')
Healing a sore muzzle and mange in animals (holy water, or 'blasphemous' cake with '+ Christus Brutus et dutus est Vanum')
Healing haemorrhoids (saliva application, Pater Nosters, Ave Marias)
Healing epilepsy/falling sickness (speaking 'Oremus praeceptis salutaribus moniti' into ear, Lord's Prayer)
Stopping blood ('SANGUIS mane in te sicut fecit Christus')
Protection against fire ('IN te, Domine, speravi')
Healing fevers in humans (prayer invoking Jesus, Mary, Saints, wearing written spell)

relevant_quotes.text: HE following secrets are sure and infallible. Guidon¹, who practised them daily, has used them to effect cures that have been proven effective beyond any shadow of doubt.
Beati tornitis omnes Joannes Baptisantes et agentes.2
Herego gomet hunc gueridans sesserant deliberant amei.3
Demon, leave the body of N. (say the name), by the commandment of the God whom I adore, and make way for the Holy Spirit.
Adibaga, Sabaoth, Adonay, contrà ratout prisons prerunt fini unixio paracle gossum.5
Avir sunt before you paracletur strator verbonum offisum fidando.9
UNITE them, unite them, wed us and wed them, untie us and wed them to Beelzebub. This charm is both dangerous and controversial.19
Rou and Rouvayet, come here, I take you on for my servant.

Scab - I conjure you in the name of Lucifer, Beelzebuth and Satanas, the three princes of all the devils, that you must stop. Repeat the above words for nine successive days and escew all Christian acts during this time.29
+ Christus Brutus et dutus est Vanum.43

The Grimoire of Pope Honorius was nothing to do with either pope of that name. It is magic of the ecclesiastical underground, using Christian forces to compel demonic agencies to perform morally dubious tasks useful to the magician.
Crouay: is most enigmatic, and may relate to romance language roots pertaining to the words for crown, cross or blood.

critical_analysis.relevance: Guidon's 'Magic Secrets' is a highly relevant document for understanding the practical application of magic in a specific historical and cultural context (17th-century Catholic France). It provides a rare 'operative' perspective of a folk practitioner or 'Cunning Man,' moving beyond the theoretical or compilational nature of many grimoires. Its syncretic blend of Christian prayers, saintly invocations, and clearly demonic or obscure pre-Christian entities (such as Crouay and Sathan) offers unique insights into the adaptability and pragmatic nature of folk magic. The explicit instructions for both protective and aggressive/compelling magic (e.g., the animal heart ritual to kill a malefactor) challenge simplistic classifications of magical practice. The afterword's discussion of witchcraft trials, particularly involving shepherds and blacksmiths in Normandy, further contextualizes the dangers and societal role of such magical operations, highlighting the fine line between acceptable folk healing and condemned sorcery. It serves as a valuable primary source for studying the 'ecclesiastical underground' and the intersection of faith and magic.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Historically, the original target audience would have been rural communities, primarily shepherds, horsemen, and individuals seeking practical magical solutions for animal welfare, crop protection, defense against malevolent spells, and personal needs (e.g., healing, treasure finding). In contemporary terms, the primary audience consists of academic researchers in Western Esotericism, occult studies, anthropology, and history, as well as practitioners of various magical traditions (especially those interested in grimoire magic, folk magic, or historical operative systems). It would appeal to those seeking a deeper, technical understanding of historical magical mechanics and the nuanced relationship between magic, religion, and society.
